primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in a fallen, 'dead' world to make humanity alive together with Christ, moving from a state of wrath to a state of grace without human merit.

tekstueel_bewijs: God... made us alive together with Christ
God, who is rich in mercy... loved us
by grace you have been saved
made us alive together with Christ
God, who is rich in mercy, out of the great love with which he loved us
by grace you have been saved
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is explicitly placed as the passive Receiver of an action already completed.

helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject; Christ is the Mediator/Helper through whom the action is realized.
helper.rol_van_geest: The Spirit is mentioned as the one calling the church into being (External/Corporate power).

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, and the 'Prince of Darkness'
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but 'death' and 'cosmic dislocation,' requiring a divine Subject to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The church (saved ones) acts as a 'resistance movement' to hold ground and enact grace in a fallen world.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Church/Believers
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Enacting victorious grace/Holding territory for the King
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is explicitly a consequence of the primary program (salvation). We act because we have been saved.

voorbeelden_mens_subject: We live in the passions of our flesh
We are called to stand our ground
We have daily opportunities to enact grace

voorbeelden: What we are called to do and be
following the desires of body and mind
We need to be frequently reminded
by grace you have been saved

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on God's 'Pouvoir' (Power) to save those who are 'dead' (lacking all competence). Human 'Devoir' is repositioned as a response to divine 'Pouvoir'.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (Death/Wrath) to S1 (Grace) via the negation of human effort (~S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'But God' moment—a divine intrusion that bypasses human merit.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the sermon uses graphic examples of evil to ensure S2 is not trivialized.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is a textbook example of grace-oriented homiletics. It maintains God as the Subject of salvation and treats human action as a secondary response to a completed divine act.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: The grace of God is mediated... by simple, quotidian acts of love

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Just saved. Saved not by our efforts, saved not by our virtues.
Even when we were dead... [God] made us alive.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The story of the mother and the airport passengers serve as 'signposts' or 'mediations' of grace, but they are explicitly labeled as enactments of God's prior victory, not as the means of salvation.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: The Prodigal Son (as a recipient of grace)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading by framing these acts as 'God's liberation'.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief, gratitude, and a sense of being part of a 'resistance movement'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation followed by synergistic sanctification.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Fundamental Program' (Salvation) to the 'Secondary Program' (Ethics) is logically and theologically seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between the 'world not being a good place' and the 'beauty of the countryside'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: There but for the grace of God goes John Bradford... gratitude to the Lord for saving us in spite of ourselves.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit calls the church into being to 'enact' what God has already won.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is described as 'deadness' and 'cosmic dislocation'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is powered by God's mercy. The human subject is only activated after being 'made alive' by the divine subject.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for a sermon on Ephesians 2.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (evil/death) is already very intense.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon masterfully avoids the trap of moralism by grounding every human action in the prior, finished work of God.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While rhetoric would look at the use of pathos in the Megan Kanka story, Greimasian analysis shows that these stories serve to define the 'Opponent' as too powerful for a human 'Subject' to defeat.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains what Paul meant; semiotics shows how the preacher has constructed a world where the hearer is the beneficiary of a cosmic rescue.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Elaine' story is not a moral example of what we should do, but a 'Helper' actant illustrating how the 'Sender' (God) mediates values into the world.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace' effectively by ensuring the 'But God' transition is the hinge of the narrative.
